properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm is expected. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snow, rain and wind is expected. Total snowfall: 10 to 20 cm. Total rainfall: 10 to 20 mm. Maximum wind gusts: 90 km/h. Locations: Iles de la Madeleine. Time span: Tuesday night, improving on Wednesday. Remarks: Snow is expected to begin late Tuesday afternoon or early Tuesday evening then change through ice pellets or freezing rain to rain later Tuesday night. Very strong easterly winds gusting up to 90 km/h are expected to accompany the precipitation. A period of low visibility in blowing snow is also likely before the changeover to ice pellets or freezing rain. In addition, higher than normal water levels and large waves are expected Tuesday night. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2021-01-31T23:48:30-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-01-31T07:49:30-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2838805855.2021
Area: ÃŽles-de-la-Madeleine
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snow, rain and wind is expected. Total snowfall: 5 to 20 cm. Total rainfall: 30 to 60 mm. Maximum wind gusts: 70 km/h except 100 along parts of the coast. Locations: Nova Scotia. Time span: Tuesday morning until Wednesday. Remarks: Snow is expected to begin early Tuesday morning over southwestern Nova Scotia and then spread northeastward reaching Cape Breton by Tuesday afternoon. The snow will change to rain throughout the province Tuesday night. A period of ice pellets or freezing rain is likely during the changeover. Very strong easterly winds will accompany the precipitation. In addition, high water levels and large waves are expected especially along the Atlantic Coast near high tide Tuesday night. Conditions will improve during the day Wednesday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-01T00:02:08-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-01-31T08:03:08-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3961276976.2021

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snow, rain and wind is expected. Total snowfall: 15 to 25 cm. Total rainfall: 10 to 20 mm. Maximum wind gusts: 70 to 90 km/h. Locations: Prince Edward island. Time span: Tuesday and Tuesday night, improving on Wednesday. Remarks: Snow is expected to begin near noon Tuesday then change through ice pellets or freezing rain to rain Tuesday night. Very strong easterly winds gusting up to 90 km/h are expected to accompany the precipitation. A period of low visibility in blowing snow is also likely before the changeover to ice pellets or freezing rain. In addition, higher than normal water levels and large waves are expected Tuesday night. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to PEstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #PEStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-01T00:01:21-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Potential winter storm over Eastern Quebec A developing low pressure system will track up the Eastern Seaboard on Tuesday and become a major storm. Heavy snow, strong winds and blowing snow that will accompany this system will reach several areas of Eastern Quebec Tuesday evening. Snowfall amounts could exceed 30 centimetres locally with higher amounts expected during the night. These poor weather conditions will continue until Wednesday. The track of this coastal low pressure system remains uncertain. Snowfall amounts will vary depending on this track. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-01T02:21:29-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-01-31T10:22:29-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1859217183.2021

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snow, rain and wind is expected. Total snowfall: 10 to 30 cm except higher amounts in some northern localities. Total rainfall: 10 to 30 mm in southern areas. Maximum wind gusts: 50 to 60 km/h except 90 along parts of the coast. Locations: New Brunswick Time span: Tuesday and Tuesday night, improving Wednesday. Remarks: Snow is expected to begin Tuesday morning in the southwest and then spread northeastward reaching northeastern regions by Tuesday evening. Over the southern half of the province, a changeover to rain is expected. During the changeover, a period of ice pellets or freezing rain is likely. Strong easterly winds will accompany the precipitation. Poor visibility in blowing snow is expected, especially in northern areas of the province. In addition, higher than normal water levels and large waves are expected along the coast of the Gulf of St. Lawrence Tuesday night. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2021-01-31T23:34:38-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-01-31T07:35:38-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3929948577.2021

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow over Southern and Central Quebec on Tuesday. A developing low pressure system will track up the Eastern Seaboard on Tuesday and become a major storm. Snow is expected to begin during the day on Tuesday and persist into the evening. This snow combined with moderate winds will generate local blowing snow. Snowfall amounts could reach between 10 and 20 centimetres. The track of this coastal low pressure system remains uncertain. Snowfall amounts expected over the province will vary depending on this track. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-01T02:37:21-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-01-31T10:38:21-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2694195952.2021

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with poor visibility in snow and blowing snow are expected tonight and Monday. Winds are forecast to increase to 70 km/h near the Richardson Mountains late this evening. This will bring blizzard conditions to the region which will likely persist until Monday evening. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #YTStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-01T04:19:08-00:00

Area: Dempster

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm is expected. A Pacific frontal system has spread 10 to 15 cm of snow over the Fraser Canyon - south including Lytton last night. Another 5 cm of snow is expected this morning before the snow changes over to rain near noon. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snow, ice pellets, rain and strong wind is expected mid week. Locations: Newfoundland. Time span: Tuesday night through midday on Thursday. Remarks: Snow is expected to begin Tuesday night, and to then transition through ice pellets before changing to rain Wednesday. Strong winds will also develop Tuesday night, with the highest gusts occurring over areas prone to enhanced southeasterlies. Conditions will improve after midday on Thursday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2021-02-01T06:12:59-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-01-31T14:13:59-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2656961663.2021

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. A long duration snowfall event will begin this morning with 50 to 70 cm of snowfall expected over portions of highway 93 by Tuesday evening. ### Road closures are likely. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Elevated pollution levels are expected or occurring. Higher pollution levels are expected to improve this morning. ### Individuals may experience symptoms such as increased coughing, throat irritation, headaches or shortness of breath. Children, seniors, and those with cardiovascular or lung disease, such as asthma, are especially at risk. Exposure to air pollution is particularly a concern for children, the elderly, and those who have underlying medical conditions such as lung or heart disease. For more information please visit Alberta Health Services at www.albertahealthservices.ca/news/air.aspx. Visit www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2021-01-31T20:23:56-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, Alberta Environment and Parks, Alberta Health, Alberta Health Services, 2021-01-31T11:43:56-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3815576398.2021
